unnormalised: Okay, so you know how things work in India, right? Especially when it comes to government stuff? It's not always as straightforward as you'd think! One of the things that always gets me is understanding all the different titles people hold. It can be a real head-scratcher, especially when you're just trying to get something done.
normalised: Okay, so you know how things work in India, right? Especially when it comes to government stuff? It's not always as straightforward as you would think! One of the things that always gets me is understanding all the different titles people hold. It can be a real head-scratcher, especially when you are just trying to get something done.

unnormalised: Like, you go to a government office, and everyone's got a title – “Shri. Sharma, IAS Officer”, “Smt. Verma, Deputy Director”, “Mr. Khan, Section Officer”. It's like a whole different language! And honestly, sometimes it feels like you need a decoder ring just to figure out who you're supposed to talk to. You might think talking to the 'Chief Secretary' is the way to go, but perhaps the 'Under Secretary' is the one handling the paperwork.

You might think talking to the 'Chief Secretary' is the way to go, but perhaps the 'Under Secretary' is the one handling the paperwork.

unnormalised: Then there are the local-level titles, like "Sarpanch" of a village, or "Ward Councillor" in a city. These folks are super important for getting things done at the grassroots level, but if you're not familiar with the local governance structure, you might not even know they exist! And sometimes, these titles can be a bit misleading. For example, the 'Block Development Officer (BDO)' might not actually be *building* anything directly, but overseeing the development schemes in an area.

unnormalised: It's not just the formal titles either. Often, you'll hear people using honorifics like "Ji" after someone's name, or calling someone "Sahab" – especially for higher-ranking officials. These aren't official titles, but they show respect and can make a big difference in how you're treated. You gotta remember your "Sir" and "Madam" too, especially when dealing with anyone in a position of authority.

These positions often oversee entire districts and have enormous administrative responsibilities.
